reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s “value as a product of factors” model and the associated picture of eutopian fragility (Section 2.4), which is an important support for the intuitive case that mostly-great futures are rare, but not the whole argument: the essay also argues fussiness via bounded/unbounded value functions, scaling, and aggregation choices. So centrality is moderate. The critique’s main point—that dimensions like population ethics, digital welfare, and wellbeing theory are interdependent and path-dependent—is plausible, but it doesn’t substantially refute the position: (i) the essay presents the product model as a toy/illustrative model with ‘relatively independent’ factors, not a literal probabilistic estimator; (ii) strong interactions/feedback could make the target narrower (harder), not broader; and (iii) the critique claims “probability estimates” are overconfident, but the essay largely refrains from producing concrete probability estimates. Correctness is mixed: the complexity/interaction objections are broadly right, but the “meaningless”/“systematically overconfident” framing overstates what the paper commits to. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Interacting value dimensions invalidate the separable product decomposition
